title: Mobile Development Exam
content:
Handling UI State Preservation in Android

In Android, activities may be destroyed and recreated due to system constraints, such as low memory, which can lead to the loss of UI state and data. Describe how Android handles such cases by default [2 marks] and the various strategies developers can use to preserve UI state across activity destruction and recreation [3 marks]. Specifically, explain how onSaveInstanceState() and ViewModel help in preserving UI data [2 marks]. Discuss the advantages and limitations of each approach [2 marks]. Provide specific examples of scenarios where each method would be most appropriate, such as using onSaveInstanceState() to preserve small UI elements like text input, and ViewModel for larger, more complex data sets that need to persist through configuration changes [1 mark].

Answer:

1. Default Handling by Android (2 marks)

By default, when an activity is destroyed and recreated (e.g., screen rotation), Android calls onSaveInstanceState() to store UI-related data in a Bundle, which is restored in onCreate() or onRestoreInstanceState(). However, only primitive data types (e.g., strings, numbers) are saved, while complex data like lists or objects require additional handling.

2. Strategies for Preserving UI State (3 marks)

Developers can use different strategies to preserve UI state:

  1. onSaveInstanceState(Bundle)
    • Saves lightweight UI-related data such as form input, scroll positions, and selection states.
  2. ViewModel
    • Keeps temporary data like a list of books, user progress, or search results even when the screen rotates, ensuring a smooth user experience.
  3. Persistent Storage (SharedPreferences, Room Database, or Files)
    • Saves long-term data like user preferences, book lists, or notes that should be available even after the app is closed.

3. How onSaveInstanceState() and ViewModel Help in Preserving UI Data (2 marks)

  1. onSaveInstanceState(Bundle)
    • Saves small UI data (e.g., text input) in a Bundle before an activity is destroyed.
    • Restores data in onCreate() when the activity is recreated (e.g., after screen rotation).
  2. ViewModel
    • Keeps temporary app data (e.g., shopping cart items) even when the configuration changes.
    • Unlike onSaveInstanceState(), it doesn’t reset after process death.

4. Advantages and Limitations (2 marks)

Approach Advantages Limitations
onSaveInstanceState() Simple, fast, and automatically restored Limited to small data (e.g., String, Int), not suitable for large datasets
ViewModel Keeps data when the screen rotates without slowing down the app. Data is lost if the app is fully closed or killed.

5. Best Use Cases (1 mark)

  • Use onSaveInstanceState() when preserving small UI-related data, such as:
    • Typed text in a form
    • Scroll position in a RecyclerView
    • Selected tab in a ViewPager
  • Use ViewModel for larger and reusable data, such as:
    • A list of books retrieved from an online library
    • User’s reading progress and preferences
    • Any data that should stay the same when rotating the screen or switching between pages

Android Application Development

You are tasked with developing an Android application that serves as a personal library for tracking books and reading progress. The app should allow users to add and store book entries, including the title, author, genre, and a brief description. Users should also be able to mark their current reading status (e.g., “Reading”, “Completed”, or “Wishlist”) and log notes about each book.

Describe the Android application components you would implement [3 marks], the architecture for the application [4 marks], and the relationship between the components [3 marks].

Answer:

**1. **Android Application Components (3 marks)

The app will use the following core Android components:

  1. Activity (Main Screens of the App)
    • MainActivity: Shows the list of books.
    • BookDetailActivity: Displays details of a selected book and allows users to update status or add notes.
    • AddBookActivity: Lets users add new books to the library.
  2. Service (For Background Tasks, Optional)
    • If the app needs to sync books with cloud storage, a background service (WorkManager or Foreground Service) can handle it.
  3. Content Provider (For Data Sharing, Optional)
    • If the app needs to share book data with other apps, a ContentProvider can provide access.

2. Application Architecture (4 marks)

The app follows the MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel) architecture:

  1. Model (Data Layer)
    • Room Database: Stores books persistently.
    • BookDao: Defines SQL queries (e.g., insert, fetch books).
    • Repository: Manages data flow between the database and UI.
  2. ViewModel (Logic Layer)
    • BookViewModel: Handles book operations and updates UI via LiveData.
  3. View (UI Layer)
    • Activities: Manage user interactions.
    • RecyclerView + Adapter: Displays the book list efficiently.

Relationship Between the Components (3 marks)

  1. User Interaction
    • Users browse books in MainActivity.
    • Clicking a book opens BookDetailActivity to update status or notes.
    • AddBookActivity allows adding new books.
  2. Data Processing
    • BookViewModel manages book data through BookRepository.
    • LiveData updates the UI automatically when data changes.
  3. Data Storage
    • BookRepository saves book data in Room Database.
    • BookDao handles database queries.
    • If cloud sync is needed, a Service manages it.

Example Flow:

  • User adds a book → AddBookActivity calls BookViewModel.addBook()
  • ViewModel updates Repository, which stores data in Room
  • LiveData notifies MainActivity, updating the book list automatically.

  1. Starting from Android 8.0 (Oreo), implicit broadcasts (those without a specific target app) can no longer be registered in the manifest, but they can still be dynamically registered at runtime.

    • [x] True
    • [ ] False

    (2 marks)

  1. An Intent in Android can only be used to start activities; it cannot be used to start services or broadcast messages.

    • [ ] True
    • [x] False

    (2 marks)

  • Intent can be used for activities, services, and broadcasts

  1. All dangerous permissions must be declared in the app’s AndroidManifest.xml file, but they can be automatically granted without user intervention if declared correctly.

    • [ ] True
    • [x] False

    (2 marks)

  • They are not automatically granted, even if declared in AndroidManifest.xml

  1. In a Recycler View, if you update the data set, the changes will automatically reflect in the UI without calling any additional methods.

    • [ ] True

    • [x] False

    (2 marks)

  • Need notifyDataSetChanged()

  1. In Android, a Service must always run in a separate process from the main application.

    • [ ] True
    • [x] False

    (2 marks)

  • A Service runs in the main application process unless explicitly set otherwise

  1. In Android, the onCreate() method is the first callback method called during the lifecycle of an activity.

    • [x] True
    • [ ] False

    (2 marks)

  1. The "R.java" file in Android is a dynamically generated file that contains resource IDs for all the resources in your app.

    • [x] True
    • [ ] False

    (2 marks)

  1. In Android, the ViewGroup class is a subclass of the View class and can contain other views.

    • [x] True
    • [ ] False

    (2 marks)

  1. The Room persistence library allows direct database access on the main thread by default.

    • [ ] True
    • [x] False

    (2 marks)

  • Performing database operations on the main thread can block the UI, so Room prevents it.
  1. What are components of Android Jetpack?
  • [x] Core utilities like AppCompat
  • [x] Lifecycle-aware components like ViewModel, LiveData, and Room
  • [x] Utilities for background tasks such as WorkManager
  • [ ] A modern toolkit for building native Android user interfaces declaratively with XML
    • it does not rely on XML
  • [ ] Components for linking XML directly to the manifest
    • Jetpack does not provide such a feature

(2 marks)

  1. What are some features of Jetpack Compose that enhance UI development in Android?
  • [x] Use of composable functions for building UI components
    • uses Kotlin functions annotated with @Composable to build UI
  • [ ] Replaces Java with Swift for UI design
    • Swift is used for iOS development
  • [x] Real-time UI updates with hot reloading
    • supports live previews and hot reloading
  • [x] Reduces the need for XML layouts
    • define UI entirely in Kotlin
  • [ ] Requires constant internet connectivity to function
    • It is a UI framework that works offline within the app

(2 marks)

  1. Which of the following are good practices to prevent an Application Not Responding (ANR) error in Android apps?
  • [ ] Running all tasks on the main thread to avoid thread switching
    • The UI thread should handle only UI-related tasks
  • [x] Offloading time-consuming operations to background threads using AsyncTask, Thread, or WorkManager
  • [x] Avoiding blocking operations like network requests or database queries on the main thread
    • Network calls, database queries, or file I/O should never run on the UI thread
  • [ ] Using Thread.sleep() on the UI thread to free up memory
    • It is a bad practice
  • [ ] Updating the UI only from background threads
    • UI updates must always be done on the main thread

(2 marks)

  1. Which of the following are recommended ways to handle long-running tasks in Android without blocking the main thread?
  • [ ] Using Thread.sleep() on the main thread to simulate delays.
    • Freezes the UI and can cause ANRs
  • [x] Using Handler to post updates from a background thread to the main thread.
  • [x] Using Thread and posting results to the main thread with Handler.post().
    • A separate Thread runs the long task, and Handler.post() updates the UI
  • [ ] Running background operations directly in the onCreate() method of an activity.
    • Blocks UI thread; should use background threads instead.
  • [ ] Using WorkManager’s update UI function.
    • WorkManager is designed for background tasks but does not have a built-in UI update function

(2 marks)

  1. Why does the app crash when updating the UI from a background thread?
  • [ ] The Looper object is not initialized in the background thread.
    • Looper is only needed if a background thread needs to process messages
  • [x] UI updates must only happen on the main thread, and performing UI changes from a background thread can cause a crash.
  • [ ] The app is missing the necessary permission to update UI components from any thread.
    • No special permissions are required to update UI elements
  • [ ] The background thread does not have access to the UI components due to permission restrictions.
    • It’s just not allowed due to thread safety
  • [ ] The background thread is using Handler incorrectly to post messages to the UI thread.
    • The issue arises only when updates are made directly from a background thread.

(2 marks)

  1. Why does the service not restart after it is killed by the system?

  • [x] The service is returning START_NOT_STICKY in onStartCommand().

    • START_NOT_STICKY means the system will not restart the service if it is killed due to low memory

  • [x] The service is bound to an activity, and when the activity is destroyed, the service stops.

    • If no component is bound, the service does not restart

  • [ ] The service does not declare the required permission in the manifest.

    • Permissions affect whether the service can be started,

      but they do not control whether it restarts after being killed

  • [x] The service uses IntentService, which automatically stops once it completes its task.

    • IntentService handles tasks in the background and stops itself once it completes execution

  • [ ] The service is running as a foreground service and should not be restarted by the system.

    • Foreground services have higher priority and they can restart if set to START_STICKY

(2 marks)

  1. Why might an activity’s onCreate() method inadvertently start a second instance of the service when a configuration change occurs?
  • [ ] The service is automatically restarted by the system during configuration changes.
    • The system does not automatically restart services on configuration changes
  • [x] The onCreate() method is called again after the configuration change, and it calls startService() without checking if the service is already running.
  • [ ] The service is duplicated because onResume() is called twice during configuration changes.
    • onResume() is not responsible for starting a service
  • [ ] The service was bound to the activity and gets recreated when the activity restarts.
    • This will not create a second instance
  • [x] The service does not have proper lifecycle management implemented.

(2 marks)

  1. Why should developers use ProGuard in their Android projects?
  • [x] To optimize the APK size by removing unused code and resources.
  • [ ] To optimize permission requests to only those which are necessary.
    • ProGuard does not modify permissions
  • [ ] ProGuard improves the runtime performance of an app by converting Java code to native code.
    • ProGuard does not convert Java to native code
  • [ ] To prevent the app from using deprecated APIs in production builds.
    • ProGuard does not check for deprecated APIs
  • [ ] It is required by Google Play for all apps to reduce security vulnerabilities.
    • Google Play does not require ProGuard

(2 marks)

  1. Why would a periodic task scheduled with WorkManager not execute periodically?
  • [x] The device is in Doze mode, which prevents periodic tasks from running on time.
  • [ ] The periodic task does not work if the app does not have the INTERNET permission.
    • WorkManager does not require INTERNET permission
  • [ ] WorkManager was not declared in the manifest.
    • WorkManager does not require manual manifest registration
  • [ ] WorkManager tasks are not designed for periodic execution and should be used only for one-time tasks.
    • WorkManager supports both one-time and periodic tasks
  • [x] The task constraints (e.g., network or battery conditions) are not satisfied, so the task is deferred.

(2 marks)

  1. You are working on an Android app that uses a remote service for background data processing. The service should communicate back with the activity using callbacks, but you are unsure how to implement this with inter-process communication.
  • [x] Use Messenger to send messages between the activity and the service, and return responses with a Handler.
  • [x] Use AIDL (Android Interface Definition Language) to define an interface for communication and handle callbacks in the service.
  • [ ] Use IntentService, which supports communication between processes and automatic queuing of requests.
    • It does not support two-way communication.
  • [ ] Use JobScheduler to schedule tasks, as it automatically handles communication between components.
    • JobScheduler is used for delayed or periodic background tasks
  • [ ] Use a thread pool to handle incoming requests concurrently.
    • A thread pool can process tasks, but it does not provide IPC between an activity and a remote service

(2 marks)

  1. Your app requests permissions to access contacts and the user’s location, but during runtime, you notice that some users are encountering issues where permissions are denied, even after they granted them during installation.
  • [x] Dangerous permissions must be requested at runtime starting from Android 6.0 (Marshmallow).
  • [ ] The app should ask for permissions in the manifest and trust the system to grant them at installation.
    • Since Android 6.0, dangerous permissions must be requested at runtime
  • [x] Use requestPermissions() to request dangerous permissions during runtime.
  • [ ] Use setHighPermission alongside the permissions.
    • There is no such API as setHighPermission
  • [ ] Use the APK release version for the permissions to be granted when the app is in use.
    • Permissions work the same way in debug and release builds

(2 marks)

  1. Why might a task scheduled with WorkManager not execute immediately?
  • [x] WorkManager is designed for tasks that are deferrable and should not execute immediately.
  • [x] The task constraints, such as network availability or charging state, are not met, preventing the task from executing.
  • [x] The system is prioritizing higher-priority background tasks over your WorkManager task.
  • [ ] WorkManager tasks always run with the highest priority and should execute immediately unless there is an error in the code.
    • WorkManager tasks are low-priority by design, as they are meant for background execution
  • [ ] The WorkManager task was scheduled without using OneTimeWorkRequest or PeriodicWorkRequest.
    • Not using them does not cause execution delays

(2 marks)

  1. You are developing an app that shares files via content URIs with other apps. You want to grant temporary permissions to another app to read or write a specific file. Which of the following approaches should be used?
  • [x] Use Intent.FLAG_GRANT_READ_URI_PERMISSION to grant temporary read access to the file.
  • [x] Use Intent.FLAG_GRANT_WRITE_URI_PERMISSION to grant temporary write access to the file.
  • [ ] Store the file in external storage and make it publicly accessible to other apps.
    • Starting from Android 10, apps cannot directly access external storage files unless they own the file
  • [ ] Use a ContentProvider without any flags, as temporary permissions are automatically granted.
    • The intent flags must be used
  • [ ] Explicitly request the user’s permission to grant access using runtime permission dialogs.
    • Runtime permissions are needed to access app-owned storage but do not grant access to other apps

(2 marks)

  1. After a recent code update, users report that the app’s settings are reset to default every time the app is restarted. What could be causing this issue?
  • [x] Failing to store settings in a persistent storage like SharedPreferences or a database.
    • Temporary variables will be lost when the app restarts
  • [ ] Misusing the content provider.
    • Content Providers are not typically used for app settings—they are for sharing data between apps
  • [ ] Incorrectly handling onTemporaryPause(), leading to settings not being saved properly.
    • There is no lifecycle method named onTemporaryPause() in Android
  • [x] Overwriting settings with default values in onCreate() without checking existing preferences.
  • [ ] Not declaring the shared preferences in the manifest.
    • It does not need to be declared in the manifest

(2 marks)

  1. How does ProGuard function in reference to Android APK optimization?
  • [x] To use ProGuard, it must be enabled in the build.gradle.
    • It must be explicitly configured in build.gradle
  • [x] It minimizes APK size by removing unused code.
  • [ ] ProGuard helps in identifying and fixing security vulnerabilities in the code.
    • It does not actively detect or fix security issues
  • [ ] ProGuard automates the process of translating Java code to Kotlin.
    • Java-Kotlin interoperability is handled by the Kotlin compiler
  • [ ] It can be run to help debug your code.
    • ProGuard obfuscates the code, making debugging harder

(2 marks)

  1. In a news app, how should you handle the storage of recently viewed articles so that they persist across sessions but are also quickly accessible during runtime?
  • [x] Employing the Room database to persist detailed article data.
  • [ ] Utilizing content providers to speed up app execution.
    • It is meant for sharing data between apps, not local caching
  • [ ] Relying on SharedPreferences for structured storage of articles and content.
    • It is meant for storing small key-value data
  • [ ] Storing article details in ViewModel for immediate access.
    • ViewModel does not persist across app restarts
  • [x] Using SharedPreferences to save a list of recently viewed article IDs.

(2 marks)

  1. What are best practices when requesting permissions in an Android app?
  • [ ] Request all necessary permissions at once during the app’s first launch for efficiency.
    • Requesting too many permissions at launch confuses users and increases rejection rates
  • [x] Permissions should be requested as close as possible to the point of use.
    • Requesting permissions only when they are needed makes the request more understandable
  • [ ] Use the requestPermissions() method from a background thread for better performance.
    • Permissions must be requested from the UI thread
  • [x] Explain to the user why the permissions are needed, possibly using a pre-permission dialog (if possible).
    • If a permission is critical, providing a rationale before requesting it increases user acceptance
  • [x] Request only the minimum set of permissions necessary for the app’s functionality.
    • Requesting unnecessary permissions can make users suspicious and increase permission denial rates

(2 marks)

  1. What are important considerations when implementing remote services using Binder in Android?
  • [x] Using Messenger instead of AIDL can simplify the implementation for communication.
  • [ ] Remote services can share the same Linux user ID to increase data-sharing efficiency.
    • Apps can share the same UID using sharedUserId, but this is deprecated for security reasons.
  • [x] AIDL (Android Interface Definition Language) is used to define the interface for remote services.
  • [ ] Remote services run in the same process as the client by default.
    • By default, remote services run in a separate process
  • [x] Remote service methods should be designed to be quick and non-blocking.
    • Methods should be quick and non-blocking to avoid freezing the client

(2 marks)

  1. What are the best practices for an Android application to handle memory constraints?
  • [ ] Use static variables to retain large datasets across activity re-creations.
    • Static variables are not automatically cleared and can cause memory leaks if not handled properly
  • [ ] Store all critical data in onSaveInstanceState() to ensure it’s preserved.
    • It is designed for small UI-related data
  • [ ] Regularly call System.gc() to manually trigger garbage collection.
    • It does not guarantee immediate garbage collection and may even slow down the app
  • [x] Override onTrimMemory() to release non-critical resources when notified.
    • This method is called when the system detects low memory conditions
  • [ ] Store all critical data in onPause() to ensure it’s preserved.
    • The system may kill the app before onPause() is completed

(2 marks)

  1. What are the implications of running long-lived Services on Android app performance, especially in memory-constrained environments?
  • [x] They can lead to increased memory usage, potentially affecting overall system performance.
    • Long-running services stay in memory, consuming RAM and CPU
  • [ ] Long-lived Services enhance app performance by keeping the app active in memory.
    • It increases system load and reduces available memory for other apps
  • [x] Running multiple long-lived Services can lead to the Android system frequently invoking garbage collection.
  • [ ] The system prioritizes long-lived Services, reducing the likelihood of them being killed.
    • If memory is low, background services are among the first to be killed
  • [ ] Such Services must implement onLowMemory() to mitigate performance impacts.

(2 marks)

  1. What techniques are recommended for efficient background processing in Android apps?
  • [ ] Running intensive background tasks in the onPause() method of the Activity.
    • Running heavy tasks in onPause() blocks UI responsiveness
  • [x] Using WorkManager for tasks that need to be executed even if the app or device restarts.
    • WorkManager is designed for deferrable, guaranteed background tasks that persist across app restarts
  • [ ] Implementing a ViewModel to ensure data is passed between activities efficiently.
    • ViewModel is not for background tasks
  • [ ] Background tasks should always run on the main thread to keep the process active.
    • It causes UI freezes and ANR (Application Not Responding) errors
  • [x] Leveraging JobScheduler for periodic tasks and taking advantage of batching and timing constraints.

(2 marks)

  1. In a file download manager, you need to download large files in the background while the user performs other tasks. If the service gets interrupted (e.g., due to low memory), it should restart and resume the download when resources are available. Which settings and methods should you use for this type of service?
  • [x] Use a Foreground Service with a persistent notification to keep the user informed.
    • Foreground services run with higher priority, reducing the likelihood of being killed
  • [x] Use startService() and set the service as START_STICKY.
    • If the service is killed, START_STICKY automatically restarts it
  • [ ] Use startService() and set the service as START_NOT_STICKY.
    • START_NOT_STICKY means the service will not restart if killed
  • [x] Set the service to START_REDELIVER_INTENT to retry the download if interrupted.
    • This ensures that if the service is killed, it restarts with the same intent, resuming the download
  • [ ] Use an IntentService to manage multiple concurrent downloads.
    • IntentService stops itself after completing a task and cannot handle concurrent downloads

(2 marks)

  1. In a news app, you want to ensure the app functions correctly across various devices and Android versions. To simulate real-world usage, which testing approach and tools would be most effective?
  • [ ] Run unit tests on a local JVM without Android dependencies.
    • Unit tests do not simulate real user interactions or device-specific behavior
  • [x] Use Monkey Stress Test to generate random user events on the app.
    • The Monkey tool generates random UI interactions to simulate real-world unpredictable usage
  • [ ] Perform manual testing only on a single device.
    • An app must be tested on multiple devices and Android versions for reliability
  • [x] Use Espresso for automated UI testing across emulators and devices.
    • Espresso allows automated UI testing
  • [ ] Use logcat to monitor app behavior under stress conditions.
    • logcat helps debug issues, but it does not automate testing or simulate real-world usage

(2 marks)

  1. In a smart home app, you want to communicate with a remote service managing multiple connected devices, each needing real-time commands and status updates. Which method allows you to efficiently send commands and receive responses to this remote service?
  • [ ] Start a new Activity for each device’s commands.
    • Activities are for UI, not for managing background communication with devices
  • [ ] Use a local Bound Service to manage each device’s status updates.
    • A local Bound Service is only accessible within the same app process
  • [x] Implement AIDL to handle commands and callbacks for multiple devices.
    • AIDL allows multiple clients
  • [ ] Use IntentService to periodically check the device statuses.
    • IntentService is not designed for real-time updates because it stops after execution
  • [ ] Use a Messenger to send data and commands in a single-threaded fashion.
    • Inefficient for real-time multi-device communication

(2 marks)

  1. In a weather app, you want to periodically check for new weather updates even if the user has exited the app. Which Android component and technique would allow you to accomplish this without requiring the user’s continuous interaction?
  • [x] Use WorkManager to handle periodic tasks in a background-friendly way.
  • [ ] Use startService() to run the service indefinitely.
    • Starting from Android 8.0 (Oreo), background services started with startService() will be stopped by the system within minutes unless running in the foreground
  • [ ] Use an IntentService that checks periodically.
    • IntentService processes one request at a time and stops when finished
  • [ ] Use a Bound Service that interacts with the main activity.
    • A bound service cannot run in the background when the user exits the app
  • [ ] Implement a Background Service to handle periodic checks.
    • A background service consumes too many resources and may be killed by the system

(2 marks)

  1. In an employee management app, you want to add a feature where users can view an employee’s profile in a new screen. From this profile screen, they should be able to edit details and save changes before returning to the main employee list with updated information. Which methods will enable this functionality?
  • [x] Use setResult() in the profile screen and check the result on the employee list screen.
  • [x] Use finish() on the edit screen to return to the profile view.
  • [ ] Use startActivity() to open the profile screen, and save changes within it.
  • [x] Use startActivityForResult() to open the profile screen and return any updates.
  • [x] Pass updated data through Intent extras to the main employee list screen.

(2 marks)

  1. You are building a recipe app that displays a list of recipes. When a recipe is selected, the app should open a new screen with the recipe details. If users press the back button, they should return to the recipe list. What is the best way to handle this scenario?
  • [x] Use startActivity() to open the recipe details screen.
  • [ ] Use startActivityForResult() so the recipe list knows when a recipe has been viewed.
    • No data needs to be returned
  • [ ] Implement the recipe list and details on separate XML layouts within a single activity.
    • Using separate activities is preferred
  • [ ] Pass data back to the main list screen by setting a result in the details screen.
    • No need to pass data back
  • [x] Use finish() to close the details screen and return to the recipe list.

(2 marks)

  1. You are developing an app that allows users to upload images. Uploads may take a few seconds, and you want to ensure the UI remains responsive. How should you handle the image upload to avoid blocking the main thread?
  • [ ] Start a new activity for the upload process.
    • An upload operation should be handled in the background
  • [ ] Run the upload on the main (UI) thread since it’s a short operation.
    • Network operations should never run on the main thread, as it can freezing UI and cause ANR errors
  • [x] Use AsyncTask to manage the upload and update the UI on completion.
    • AsyncTask runs tasks in the background and updates the UI once completed
  • [ ] Use Activity.runOnUiThread() to handle the upload directly from the UI thread.
    • This will still block the UI thread since the upload is a network operation
  • [x] Use a Handler and Looper to post the upload operation to a background thread.
    • A Handler allows posting background tasks to a worker thread while keeping the UI responsive

(2 marks)

  1. You have implemented a service in your Android app, but it doesn’t start when you expect it to. What could be the reason?
  • [x] The service is not declared in the AndroidManifest.xml file.
    • All services must be explicitly declared in AndroidManifest.xml before they can be started
  • [ ] The service is declared but not exported, so it cannot start.
    • Exporting is only needed if other apps need to start the service. If it’s for internal use, this is not required
  • [x] The service is using startForeground(), but no notification is provided.
    • Android requires foreground services to show a persistent notification
  • [ ] The service is trying to bind before being started with startService().
    • A Bound Service does not require startService()
  • [x] The service is running in the background on Jetpack 8.0+ without proper handling of background execution limits.
    • Starting Android 8.0 (Oreo, API 26), background services cannot run freely unless:
      • The app is in the foreground.
      • The service is promoted to a foreground service

(2 marks)

  1. Your app needs to communicate with Android’s Power Manager to set power-saving parameters. Which approach will let you access and control this system service for power management?
  • [ ] Set up a local service with a Messenger for managing power-related settings.
    • A local service does not provide access to system-level power settings
  • [x] Use the PowerManager system service via the ServiceManager.
  • [ ] Create an IntentService that periodically updates power settings.
    • It cannot control system power settings directly
  • [ ] Utilize Binder directly to call PowerManager functions.
    • PowerManager is already exposed via a system service, so there’s no need to use Binder
  • [ ] Implement AIDL for handling all communication with the PowerManager.
    • AIDL is used for defining remote services, but PowerManager is a system service that is already available in the Android framework

(2 marks)

  1. You’re building a news app where users can read articles. You want the app to remember the scroll position in an article if the device is rotated, so users can resume reading from where they left off. Which method should you use to achieve this?
  • [x] Override onSaveInstanceState() to store the scroll position in a Bundle.
    • It stores UI-related data in a Bundle, which is restored when the activity is recreated
  • [x] Use the ViewModel to store the scroll position across activity re-creations.
    • ViewModel survives configuration changes (like rotation)
  • [ ] Use a singleton class to hold the scroll position.
    • Singletons persist longer than needed, potentially holding old data when the user reads a different article
  • [ ] Store the scroll position in SharedPreferences and reload it on activity restart.
    • It is for persistent storage, but the scroll position is temporary UI state, not long-term data
  • [ ] Save the scroll position in a file and reload it on configuration change.
    • Saving UI state in a file is overkill and unnecessary

(2 marks)
